title: 109_s1739
content: SECTION 1. RELEASE OR DETENTION OF A MATERIAL WITNESS. Amendments to Title 18 allow for the arrest of a material witness if their testimony is deemed crucial in a criminal case or before a Federal grand jury. Amendments to Title 18 authorize the arrest of a material witness if they fail to appear after being served with a summons or subpoena. A judicial officer can waive the summons or subpoena requirement if there is clear evidence that the person is likely to flee or their appearance cannot be secured. Additionally, a warrant can be issued for a material witness under specific requirements. A warrant issued under subsection (a) must contain the name or description of the material witness, specify the reason for their testimony, command their arrest, and inform them of their rights. The warrant issued under subsection (a) must contain the witness's name, reason for testimony, and rights. The warrant must inform the witness of their right to counsel, be signed by a judicial officer, and executed by arresting the witness. Upon arrest, the officer must show the warrant to the witness. The material witness must be shown the warrant by the possessing officer. If the officer does not have the warrant, they must inform the witness of its existence and purpose, and provide it upon request. After executing a warrant, an officer must return it to the judicial officer before whom the material witness is brought. An unexecuted warrant can be canceled by a judicial officer at the request of the United States Government attorney. Upon arrest, a material witness must be brought before a judicial officer without delay. The initial appearance can take place in the district of arrest or an adjacent district if more convenient. At the initial appearance, a judicial officer must inform a material witness of the warrant against them, the application and affidavit supporting the warrant, and their right to retain counsel or request appointed counsel. At the initial appearance, a judicial officer must inform a material witness of the warrant against them, the application and affidavit supporting the warrant, and their right to retain counsel or request appointed counsel. The officer must also allow the witness to consult with counsel, release or detain the witness as per subsection (d), and transfer the witness to another district if necessary. Upon appearance before a judicial officer, a material witness arrested under a warrant issued under subsection (a) must be released or detained. The release can be on personal recognizance, unsecured appearance bond, or other conditions. Upon appearance before a judicial officer, a material witness arrested under a warrant must be released or detained. The release can be on personal recognizance, appearance bond, or other conditions, unless clear and convincing evidence shows that release will not assure appearance. Testimony can be secured by deposition to avoid detention for non-compliance with release conditions. After a hearing, if a judicial officer finds that no conditions will assure a witness's appearance, they may order detention for up to 5 days or until testimony can be secured. The witness's testimony can be secured by deposition or court appearance. Detention can be extended for up to 5 days for further testimony if needed. The witness can be detained for up to 30 days in a criminal case or 10 days in other cases until their testimony is secured by deposition or court appearance. The witness can be detained for up to 30 days in a criminal case or 10 days in other cases until their testimony is secured by deposition or court appearance. A motion must show good cause for why the witness's testimony could not be obtained earlier. Factors are considered when deciding whether to release or detain a material witness. When determining whether to release or detain a material witness, factors such as the witness's history and characteristics are considered. Challenges to the warrant may also be taken into account. Release orders must meet specific requirements, while detention orders have their own set of criteria. A detention order for a material witness must comply with specific requirements, including being held separately from individuals facing criminal charges and under the least restrictive conditions possible. The Attorney General is required to report to the Committees on relevant matters. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on the use of warrants under this section by the US Government. The report should include the number of warrants sought, granted or denied, and the number of material witnesses arrested whose testimony was not secured. Rule 46(h) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to require the court to supervise the detention of defendants awaiting trial and persons held as material witnesses to eliminate unnecessary detention.
